importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking the festival of lights and a time of renewal and community gathering globally.
Sikhs commemorate Bandi Chhor Divas on this date, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Diwali spans five days, from October 20 to October 24, during which communities engage in religious, cultural, and social traditions across South Asia and diaspora regions.

keyTakeAways: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is one of the biggest festivals in India and is celebrated by Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists.

The festival marks the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and is rooted in various legends including the return of Rama and Sita, the defeat of Narakasura, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings.
Diwali is celebrated over five days: Dhanteras, Choti Diwali, Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa (Govardhan Puja), and Bhai Dooj, each with distinct rituals and traditions.
The festival transcends religious boundaries and is now widely celebrated by people of various faiths and cultures, reflecting its cultural and symbolic significance.
In some regions, Diwali marks the start of the new financial year, with businesses opening new accounts, and gambling is considered auspicious due to a legend involving Shiva and Parvati.
The festival is observed in India, Nepal, Malaysia, Fiji, and other countries with significant South Asian diasporas.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the festival of lights, is celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide on October 20, 2025. Rooted in myths of light triumphing over darkness, the festival spans five days, each with unique traditions: Dhanteras (buying gold and cleaning), Choti Diwali (Krishna’s defeat of Narakasura), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja and family gatherings), Padwa (marital love and Govardhan Hill story), and Bhai Dooj (sibling bonds). While primarily religious, Diwali has become a cultural celebration transcending faith, observed in India, Nepal, Malaysia, Fiji, and beyond. Key religious interpretations include Rama and Sita’s return, the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings (Sikhs), Lord Mahavira’s enlightenment (Jains), and Emperor Ashoka’s embrace of Buddhism (Buddhists). Traditions such as diyas, rangoli, and fireworks reflect both spiritual and social values, and the festival marks the start of a new financial year in many communities.
